description.narrative: Grantmaking to movements and communities of PLHIV/LGBTIQ/SW and PWUD in Kenya towards the protection, promotion and fulfillment of their sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) by contributing to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 3 and 5 and result areas 4 and 1 of the Dutch MoFA SRHR strategy.

title.narrative: L3. Key populations have access to inclusive, non-judgemental, gender-sensitive people-centred accountable and comprehensive HIV and SRH services that are adequately and sustainably resourced.
Description of the link between Love Alliance indicators with MoFA basket indicators
# of policies/laws/strategies currently being implemented to meet the needs of key populations as a result of programme contribution.

description.narrative: # of by-laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement.

comment.narrative: Add description of this indicator as mentioned in the baseline for Kenya
# of by-laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement.
Voices of Community Action & Leadership Kenya (VOCAL), Caucus on Harm Reduction & Policy Reform (Caucus).

title.narrative: S1. Diverse KP communities are organised and meaningfully inclusive and have strengthened their capacity to claim their rights and freedoms.
Description of the link between Love Alliance indicators with MoFA basket indicators.
S1.2 # of civil society organisations and community led organisations with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations.

comment.narrative: The national HIV strategy recognises men who have sex with men (MSM), people who inject drugs (PWID), and sex workers (SW) as key populations, and adolescent key populations are also distinctly included. Transgender people are not formally recognised as a key population (UNAIDS LPA, 2021).

At least 20 KP led civil society organisations and community led organisations in Kenya with increased capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations.
This is a target for 5 years i.e. 2021- 2025

8 KP-led civil society organisations in Kenya were supported to increase their capacity to advocate for the rights of key populations.
We targeted our capacity support towards building the ability of our partners to re-engage with key advocacy that had been interrupted due to Covid-19 and its restrictions that did not allow activists the flexibility and governments the latitude to think through the engagement of our communities.
For example it was important for our communities to re-engage with country government management health and planning teams,as such engagements provide a safe and enabling environment for the expansion of our programming into rural remote contexts that have strong cultural and or religion power systems that are difficult for our communities to negotiator through to sustain their work. The lack of such conversation had during the past led to a clamp down on our partners’ organising by religious, cultural and other cultural fundamentalists.
